newsitem.title: UK: Metals end LME mostly up, copper/aluminium firmer.
newsitem.headline: Metals end LME mostly up, copper/aluminium firmer.

text.p: Base metal markets ended a less-active Friday LME session generally steadier, with copper and aluminium showing strong gains at the end of the kerb.
Traders said the markets absorbed the expected booksquaring ahead of the weekend, with copper in particular bracing itself for the fiercely tight nearby prompts that fall due from next Monday.
Conditions picked up towards the close, when shortcovering was seen in most metals, and apart from a depressed lead market, prices concluded around their peaks.
In copper, the cash/threes spread was around $200/210, near its highs of the week with the tightness likely to be maintained next week and cash/one day rates seen flaring.
The forward market dipped back to $2,365 at one stage, but subsequently raced up to close at $2,383, up $15 a tonne, signalling another challenge of $2,400.
The labour disputes at Escondida, Quebrada Branca and Phelps Dodge, as well as the maintainance shutdown of Kennecott's smelter remained the fundamental props.
Aluminium performed strongly, and looks to have built a base above $1,600. Borrowing of early July to the July date helped the trend also, and pulled cash/threes into $25/27 contango.
Last three months business was at $1,613, up $19 from Thursday's close. Alloy was marked up and ended at $1,490/95 a tonne.
Solid fundamentals helped zinc, with last business at $1,275, up $4, while tin and nickel followed the trend, closing at $5,740 and $7,480, respective gains of $20 and $30.
However, sluggish physicals and rising stocks inhibited lead, which closed at $631, down $4.
